awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Nanopatterning and temporal control of phase-change materials for reconfigurable photonics
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to control light dynamically, commonly known as reconfigurable photonics, is ubiquitous in everyday life with diverse and varied applications ranging from supermarket barcode readers to adaptive optics for deep-space telescopes, and from dynamic theatre lighting to medical microscopy. Currently, these applications rely on spatial light modulator (SLM) technologies that have significant limits: They are slow, costly, involve fragile moving parts, and not versatile enough to adapt to modern challenges. In this project, a material known as phase-change materials (PCMs) is used to create a faster and less costly spatial light modulator. This is done by combining a type of PCM that is commonly used in Blu-Ray discs, known as GST, with new types of nanofabrication and electronic control to create advanced reconfigurable photonic devices with performance metrics that far exceed what is currently available. The benefits of this project are three fold. At the core, this project falls at the intersection between two fields of research: nanoscale thermal science, and photonics. This will lead to an advancement of both fields in a new and unexplored dimension. On the education front, the project will allow for student exchanges between the University of Dayton and Stanford University, for the first time. It will also bolster the relationship with minority-serving institutes. The longer term impact of this work will be to provide a stepping stone towards providing compact, high speed, low power consumption devices, manufactured using inexpensive fabrication methods for use in technologies based on reconfigurable photonics. 


Current state-of-the art in light modulation for reconfigurable photonic applications relies on spatial light phase modulation via liquid-crystal on silicon (LCoS) or Microelectromechanical (MEMS) systems, both of which have major limitations. One current hurdle is the speed at which these devices operates, and the other is the complexity and low-yield of their fabrication process. The goal of this research is to use phase-change materials (PCMs) for coherent spatial and temporal control of light in a lossless, high-speed manner, well beyond the performance of standard liquid crystal and MEMs devices today. PCMs alter their optical properties (refractive index) through a controlled crystalline-to-amorphous phase transition, making them ideal for light modulation applications. However, two problems persist with PCMs: a) The phase transition is slow and b) the phase transition is binary (on/off), preventing the implementation of the necessary phase modulation devices. This proposal looks at both these problems and presents a novel and unified solution based on nanopatterning and temporal control of the phase-change process. Through the use of a new and scalable technique for self-assembled patterning, we alter the temperature dynamics and increase the speed of the phase-change by orders of magnitude. By using  temporally-controlled electric stimulus, it is possible to achieve true continuous phase modulation of light overcoming the binary nature of the material itself.  Phase-change materials, which naturally lend themselves to mass manufacturing, have the potential to alter the area of reconfigurable photonics and light modulation devices provided their full potential is exploited. This project aims to achieve that potential through a new collaboration between fields of engineering that typically do not see much overlap. Ultimately, the goal is to implement basic spatial light modulation devices, with unique engineered thermal properties, which presents a new cross-pollination of these fields, which could lead to further developments in both areas of science.

por.por_cntn:
Our project involved the developed of phase change materials as a novel mechanism for light control at the nanoscale. Phase change materials are a class of optical thin films capable of changing between a disordered (amorphous) and an ordered (crystalline) state based on optical or electrical excitation. As each state possesses different optical properties, our aim was to control the material to create new types of technologies. Within that field of research, we focused on three critical applications for future technologies: Spatial Light Modulation, Polarization Control, and Photonic Memories. Spatial Light modulators are a ubiquitous tool for light control, that enable the control of the amplitude and phase of light, and is an enabling platform for applications ranging from projection displays, Virtual/Augmented reality, laser light shaping for applications in medical imaging and additive manufacturing, beam steering for laser detection and ranging. Polarization control is critical for applications such as quantum communications and free-space optical communications for space and terrestrial stations. Photonic memories, on the other hand, will be a cornerstone of future optical computers based on neural networks that mimic the human brain and are suited towards artificial intelligence applications.

Intellectual Merit:

This project has yielded three outcomes that are highlighted in this Projects Outcome summary. First, we developed a viable, all-optical memory in the telecommunications band. The memory concept is shown in the Optical Memory figure. Using direct optical encoding, we were capable of storing 22 levels of optical information into a single spatial location. This memory will form the cornerstone of an all-optical photonic computing protocol for image classification, based on an artificial neural network. Second, we developed a high-speed, electrically actuated pixel (Figure Spatial Light Modulator Pixel) based on novel doped phase change materials (tungsten-doped germanium antimony telluride, WGST). This is a first demonstration of high speed actuation of WGST through direct Joule heating, a critical step that enables very efficient operation as it does not require an external heating mechanism. The high-speed nature (MHz speed) of light modulation is two orders of magnitude faster than current state of the art using liquid crystal devices. Finally, for the very first time, we have demonstrated new types of chiral nanostructures, capable of controlling the polarization of light (Figure Chiral nanostructure ) at the nanoscale (250 nm and below), and will be a platform for a new class of devices for fundamental studies into the vector nature of light, as well means for enabling future technologies in quantum and classical free-space communications.

Broader Impacts

The project has enabled 2 full PhD theses  to be completed in the three year time-frame, one on Photonic Memories, and one on Spatial Light Modulation and Polarization Control at the Nanoscale, in addition to one Masters thesis. One of the students is moving to industry, while the other two are continuing into an academic career. Additionally, 3 undergraduate students have been involved in the project with all of them moving to graduate school in top-level schools. The project has been a contributor to NSF's educational mission by educating multiple students and preparing to be part of the next generation of workforce in industry and acadmia.

Additionally, the project has been critical in ensuring the success of a diverse body of students at UD and beyond. As part of the effort, a collaboration between the University of Dayton and Morehouse College allowed UD to recruit undergraduate (via REU), MS, and PhD students from Morehouse, and helped establish a viable collaboration between a research institution and the top school for graduating minority physics students. This collaboration will continue through a summer research  initiative at UD for underserved minority students (currently in its 3rd year). 

Finally, we anticipate that the technology developed throughout the life of this project will allow the PI, in coordiation  with the University to transition some of the developments into an industrial, mature setting, through an effort for harnessing phase-change material-based spatial light modulators for wide commercial use in the near future.
